title: HPHT Narrow Mud Weight Window Management
question: On {{wellProfile.wellName}}, you are drilling at {{currentSection.settingDepth.tvd}} {{currentSection.settingDepth.unit}} TVD in an HPHT section. Pore pressure is {{scenario.porePressure}} ppg and fracture gradient is {{scenario.fracGradient}} ppg. Your mud weight window is only {{scenario.windowSize}} ppg. Current MW is {{currentSection.mudWeight.current}} ppg. What is the MAXIMUM ECD you can tolerate before risking losses?

steps: The maximum ECD is the fracture gradient at TD
Available ECD increase = Frac Gradient - Current MW
This is your operating margin for circulation

feedback.correct: Correct. Maximum ECD = {{scenario.fracGradient}} ppg (the fracture gradient). With current MW of {{currentSection.mudWeight.current}} ppg, you have only {{availableMargin}} ppg ECD margin. Monitor PWD closely.
feedback.incorrect: Maximum ECD equals the fracture gradient at TD: {{scenario.fracGradient}} ppg. Exceeding this risks lost circulation and potential well control complications.

contextualTip: With a {{scenario.windowSize}} ppg window on {{wellProfile.wellName}}, you're walking a tightrope. A kick adds pressure (toward frac gradient), but weighting up to kill also adds pressure. This is why HPHT wells use MPD and careful ECD management.
